Award.AwardTitle: CIF21 DIBBs: EI: Vizier, Streamlined Data Curation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Big Data promises to have a positive impact on many aspects of our lives, but assembling the data to answer questions or derive predictive models can be challenging. Data scientists must typically go through multiple rounds of curation, or 'wrangling,' where data are organized, refined, cleaned up, and merged together before they can be analyzed. Curation is often slow and costly, but is essential for obtaining useful and trustworthy answers. This project develops a software tool called Vizier that aims to streamline data curation and enable domain experts who do not have computer science expertise to curate their own data. Easier curation magnifies the value of big data by enabling a wide range of users to improve data quality, and in doing so benefits numerous types of data-driven work in government, industry, and science.

Vizier features an intuitive interface combining elements of notebooks and spreadsheets, allowing analysts to quickly see, edit, and revise data. This capability is complemented by a framework for automated data cleaning steps that are seamlessly integrated with manual curation operations. The heart of Vizier is a system for managing uncertainty and provenance of curation workflows and data, enabling the user to keep track of higher-level curation operations as well as track the lineage of data. By transparently maintaining the history of all the user's actions and their effect on the curated data, Vizier enables regret-free exploration and curation where any changes to the data and their transitive effects can be undone. By learning from past curation histories, the system will also be able to provide users with context-dependent recommendations for additional curation actions.

This award by the Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Division is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences (Division of Social and Economic Sciences).

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project developed the Vizier notebook, an open-source tool for reproducible data exploration and curation (https://github.com/VizierDB). Vizier provides a user-friendly way for data scientists and engineers to collaboratively prepare, transform, clean, debug, and analyze data; pivoting between programming and query languages (Scala, Python, SQL), direct data manipulation through spreadsheets, and standardized data transformation and curation widgets called Lenses. Detailed provenance information is automatically collected for each dataset, file, or other artifact produced by Vizier: each artifact, and even its component parts (e.g., individual data values) can be traced back through the workflow steps that generated or modified them. The provenance information supports transparency and provides an explanation for how data is derived. It also can be used to reproduce the steps, or apply them over different data -- allowing existing workflows to be adapted for new data.

Vizier aids analysts in judging the trustworthiness of their results by keeping track of how data preparation and curation operations affect the results of an analysis. This is achieved through a novel technique called caveats: User- or system-created annotations on data that indicate a concern, error, or relevant context. Caveats "stick" to data, even when through transformations. Vizier supports light-weight visualizations of caveats that indicate to the analyst which data values, columns, rows, or whole datasets are derived from caveated data and, thus, are potentially untrustworthy (e.g., "this result should be investigated further, because it depends on many imputed missing values.").

Vizier is in active use, driving ETL workflows for researchers in disciplines including Materials Science, Food Systems and Planning, and Healthcare. Throughout these use cases, Vizier has consistently made it easy to incorporate feedback from consumers of the datasets generated from workflows; Vizier's provenance tracking makes it easy to identify sources of error and resolve them.

Recently, Michael Brachmann (a researcher programmer hired though this grant), together with the PIs, founded Breadcrumb Analytics to provide services based on Vizier. Breadcrumb Analytics, ensures the sustainability of the Vizier project beyond the initial support provided by this grant.

In addition to actively supporting researchers in other disciplines, Vizier has contributed insights back to the data management community. Most notably, the project spawned an entirely new line of research on techniques for making incomplete data management practical. The project has also contributed new innovations in provenance for spreadsheets, lazy dependency analysis for workflows, and strategies for hybridizing coarse- and fine-grained provenance models.
